guiding_thinkers: Gillian Rose, Theodor Adorno, G.W.F. Hegel, Walter Benjamin
description: Analyzes social forms through speculative dialectics, emphasizing the broken middle, determinate negation, and the pathologies of both state and civil society

assumptions: The real is rational and the rational is real - but this is a critical, not affirmative claim
Understanding requires grasping the whole, but totality is always broken and contradictory
Concepts are not merely abstract but have real social existence and power
The 'broken middle' between universal and particular cannot be overcome by theory alone
Identity thinking that subsumes particulars under universals is a form of domination
Critique must be immanent - working from within the contradictions of existing forms
core_tensions: Universal vs Particular - abstract law versus concrete ethical life
State vs Civil Society - political form versus social content
Concept vs Object - thought's claim to grasp reality versus non-identity
Mourning vs Melancholy - working through loss versus endless repetition
scope_conditions: Applies to modern societies with developed legal-political institutions
Requires attention to both institutional forms and lived experience
Focus on how concepts mediate social relations

primary_entities: Sittlichkeit (Ethical Life) - concrete customs, institutions, and practices of a community
Concept (Begriff) - not mere abstraction but the inner structure of reality
Broken Middle - the irreducible gap between universal and particular
Second Nature - social forms that appear natural but are historically constituted
Constellation - non-hierarchical arrangement of concepts that illuminates objects
relations: Determinate Negation - critique that preserves what it negates in transformed form
Mediation - how concepts relate to objects through social practice
Recognition - mutual acknowledgment constituting subjects and institutions
Sublation (Aufhebung) - simultaneous cancellation, preservation, and elevation
levels_of_analysis: Abstract Right - formal property and contract relations
Ethical Life - family, civil society, and state as concrete totality

change_mechanisms: Dialectical development - contradictions drive transformations of social forms
Crisis of mediation - breakdown of institutions that connect universal and particular
Immanent critique - working contradictions through from within
temporal_patterns: Owl of Minerva - philosophy comprehends forms only as they pass
Repetition and difference - historical forms recur but transformed
Retroactive determination - meaning of events fixed by subsequent developments
transformation_processes: Bildung (formation) - education and self-cultivation through estrangement
Work of mourning - acknowledging loss to move beyond it
Speculative reversal - revealing the rational in what appears merely actual

key_concepts: Determinate Negation - negation that specifies what it negates and produces new content
Broken Middle - the unbridgeable gap between law and ethics, universal and particular
Non-identity - the irreducible difference between concept and object
Constellation - arrangement of concepts around an object without reducing it
Second Nature - social forms hardened into apparent naturalness
Absolute Ethical Life - the speculative unity that remains forever broken
analytical_methods: Immanent critique - testing claims against their own standards
Phenomenological reconstruction - tracing shapes of consciousness
Speculative reading - finding the rational kernel in mystified forms
Constellational analysis - arranging concepts to illuminate without subsumption
problem_diagnosis: Juridification - reduction of ethical life to abstract legal categories
Identity thinking - violent subsumption of particulars under universals
Mourning failure - inability to work through historical catastrophe
False reconciliation - premature claims to have overcome contradictions
ideal_state: Speculative experience - thinking that transforms both subject and object
Genuine reconciliation - acknowledging broken middle without false unity
Critical theory as practice - thought that changes what it comprehends
Non-dominating reason - concepts that respect non-identity of objects

trait_definitions.trait_description: Finding rational content in apparently contingent or irrational forms
Criticizing forms by their own internal standards and contradictions

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Universal principles applied without attention to concrete situations
Treating mediated social forms as natural or immediate
critique_patterns.fix: Trace how {apparent_natural} is historically constituted through {social_process}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Claiming contradictions resolved when they persist
critique_patterns.fix: Identify the unresolved tension between {thesis} and {antithesis}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Reducing particulars to instances of abstract categories
critique_patterns.fix: Attend to what in {particular} exceeds or resists {category}

historical_context: Developed from Hegel through Frankfurt School, renewed by Gillian Rose's critique of post-Hegelian thought
